Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: An attorney in a case before you has just cited a new appellate court decision from last week that could be relevant. You need to review it before the next session.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my mother’s voice echoing with pride as she handed me the ceremonial script. “You’re the eldest, it’s your turn to lead the family ritual this year. It means so much to your grandmother.” I nodded, feeling the weight of generations pressing on my shoulders. But my phone buzzed with an urgent email from my clerk: “Counsel just cited a new appellate decision—need your review before tomorrow’s hearing.” As a judge, I knew I had to read and analyze the case thoroughly; justice demanded nothing less. My family expected me to honor our traditions, to be present and lead with grace. The court expected me to be impartial and prepared, to uphold the law with diligence. My heart pounded as I stared at the script in one hand and the legal brief in the other, torn between the legacy of my family and the integrity of my profession, knowing I could not give both the attention they deserved.
